abstract.text: An attribute that represents grammatical agreement with an argument in a localized string.

inlineContent.text: Many languages require grammatical agreement in their sentences. In Spanish, for example, the adjectives and verbs need to agree with the gender of the subject they refer to in the sentence. For example, suppose you need to translate the following sentence into Spanish:
The challenge is that, most often, the localization file only contains masculine forms of translated words. So, in this sentence, the masculine words for
to agree with the feminine subject of the sentence (
You can make the first part of the sentence grammatically agree by inflecting the words
is the feminine subject of the sentence, masculine
The second part of the sentence, however, requires the
is at the end of the sentence, it needs to inflect on the subject,
, which is at the beginning. By wrapping
attribute and pointing it to the feminine word

this way eliminates the need for the localization file to include both the masculine and the feminine forms of each word. By wrapping the words needing inflection, and then pointing them to the words they need to agree with, the system achieves agreement in the localized text for you.
The following steps ensure proper gender agreement in the translation:
Create a type containing all the words you need for translation. For example, create an
structure containing two localizable string properties for
Add the necessary translations for the food items and the sizes into the Spanish localization file.
containing the English key phrase from the Spanish localization file to translate, along with placeholder variables representing the words to inflect (
In the Spanish localization file, add
placeholders for the words you want to substitute as part of the translation. Make the Spanish words for the size and the item grammatically agree using the
. Then make the masculine Spanish word for
) agree with the feminine word for
attribute, pointing to the second replacement in the sentence (
). Note how the placeholder attributes for
, reverse order in the code example below when translating from English to Spanish.
Inflect the entire sentence by passing the
instance into a new instance of

code: let order = Order(item: String(localized: "salad"), size: String(localized: "small"))
// Define the resource you want to apply grammatical agreement to.
// Make a new string imposing grammatical agreement on the resource from the localized phrase.

abstract.text: A scope for accessing an inflection rule attribute.
A scope for accessing a morphology attribute.
A scope for accessing an inflection alternative attribute.
A scope for accessing an agreement concept attribute.
A scope for accessing a referent concept attribute.
A scope for accessing an agreement argument attribute.
An attribute that represents grammatical agreement with an argument in a localized string.
An attribute that represents grammatical agreement for objects that aren’t part of the inflected text.
An attribute that provides an alternative inflection phrase when the system can’t achieve grammatical agreement.
A type for using an inflection rule as an attribute.
A type for using a morphology as an attribute.
An attribute that specifies a grammatical agreement concept for substituting pronouns in localized text.
